That's exactly it. They shouldnt nerf everything - they should buff everything to the level of the strongest one.
Thats how powercreep happens.

I think that's okay, though, in this situation.

Powercreep on champions: Bad, as it requires people to purchase new champs to remain competitive. Obsoletes old favorites, disenfranchises veterans, the whole nine yards. Players should have an even playing field, and champion powercreep prevents that in the worst possible way.

Powercreep on runes/masteries: Fine, as all champions have access to strong options. Puts flashier power on pre-game decisions, so players know what they chose influenced their game. Only works if all options are of comparable strength, as otherwise we end up with the same problems as our first example of powercreep. 

Ideally, each champ should end up with a few strategies that work well for them and make them feel unique... and I'd prefer if these were noticeably powerful.

> [{quoted}](name=Okuma,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=bUML7THT,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2017-11-08T08:05:40.359+0000)
>
> Well it's quite overtuned, don't you think?

I'm not sure. It encourages extremely risky play where you are forced to basic attack opponents after using a spell (similar to a sheen proc). As a reward for the risk you take, you have a chance to steal an item (but not really) from the player you strike. This mastery does not give any combat benefits, and as such picking it means you opt out of late game power in favour of (mainly) lane benefits. 

It promotes a very unique hit & run strategy that at the same time does not snowball the wielder. I think this is exactly what keystones should be all about.

The consumables do give combat benefits depending on what drops. "Extremely risky" is an overstatement. Trading in lane is the norm. It just encourages you to cast a spell before trading in the case of non mages, and an auto attack after a spell in the case of mages. Theres no CD to it, gives bonus gold, and gives consumables that range from giving you more chunks of gold to red elixirs to even mana pots. To top it off, whatever algorithm  they're using is actually making it proc fairly often. I agree its fun, but right now it's definitely over-tuned, and making everything else stronger to compensate for the strength of this isn't a viable option
